p.s: Description of Leptotrichia trevisanii sp. nov.
Leptotrichia trevisanii (tre.vi.san.i.i, L. gen. n. trevisanii) is derived from V. Trevisan, who proposed the name for this genus in 1879.
The organism is characterised by long, fusiform, nonmotile, Gram stain negative bacilli that are 0.8–0.9 µm wide and 6–13 µm long with tapered ends.
Cells are arranged in pairs and chains and, where they join, the ends are flattened.
Isolates are non-spore forming, catalase positive, indole negative and oxidase negative.
They are negative for urease, negative for hydrolysis of the pNP-sugars α-D-arabinoside, α-D-galactoside and α-L-fucoside and are unable to hydrolyse oNP-beta-D-galactoside.
They are positive for hydrolysis of pNP derivatives of α-D-glucoside, β-D-glucoside, N-acetyl-β-D-glucosamine and pNP-phosphate.

The organism is unable to hydrolyse the napthylamide derivatives of leucyl-glycine, glycine, proline, serine and pyrrollidone, but is able to hydrolyse arginine and phenylalanine derivatives (RapID ANA II test kit results).
Leptotrichia trevisanii grows both anaerobically and under 5% CO2 (in air) on subsequent culture on solid media.
It ferments glucose to produce lactic acid as the major organic end-product.

On horse blood agar plates, colonies appeared smooth, grayish in color, low convex and erose edged; they showed a dark central spot with transillumination and grew to about 2 mm diameter after 5 days of incubation.
Older colonies showed a slightly convoluted surface.
The type strain is Leptotrichia trevisanii strain “Wee Tee” 1999 and has been deposited with the American Type Culture Collection as ATCC 700907.
